item.title: Lawless State Capitalism Is No Answer to China’s Rise
item.description: Invoking national security and the economic rivalry with China, the Trump administration is pursuing legally dubious interventions and control of private industry, with potentially high costs for US dynamism. Like the panic over Japan's rise in the 1980s, the administration's response is unwarranted and counterproductive.

item.title: Trump’s Dangerous Disregard for International Justice
item.description: Since its founding, America has been a consistent supporter of post-conflict justice, which was a powerful tool in the diplomatic arsenal of presidents of all political stripes. Donald Trump’s disdain for international justice thus represents a historical rupture – and a potentially serious threat to peace.

item.title: The First AI Government Minister
item.description: Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama's recent appointment of an AI chatbot to his cabinet is no mere publicity stunt. Advocates of digital technocracy genuinely believe that popular sovereignty is nothing more than the consecration of incompetence, and their influence is growing.

item.title: Trump the Useful Idiot
item.description: Donald Trump has shown an almost pathological desire to tout his “fantastic” relationship with Vladimir Putin, even as Putin has discounted, disregarded, and defied him. For Chinese President Xi Jinping, too, Trump is an ideal unwitting ally in the quest to establish a geopolitical sphere of influence.

item.title: Developing Countries Are Paying Too Much to Borrow
item.description: With international financial institutions often bailing out private creditors instead of fostering recoveries for developing countries, the current financial architecture is creating a lethal debt spiral that threatens everyone. Something must change – and fast.

item.title: How Trump Could Ensure His Legacy as a Peacemaker
item.description: The US was the first country to unleash the destructive power of the atom, and with that power came a solemn responsibility. US President Donald Trump's recent meeting with Vladimir Putin did not end the war in Ukraine, but it could still serve as a first step toward restoring common-sense nuclear arms control.

item.title: India’s Reckoning With Its Dangerous Neighborhood
item.description: While the recent eruption of unrest in Nepal is not uncommon for a region that remains in perpetual crisis, it does represent a dangerous new trend. For India, the challenge is not only to maintain strategic autonomy, but to promote its vision of a more inclusive, rules-based, and connected South and Southeast Asia.

item.title: How Off-Grid Solar Can Transform an Economy
item.description: Distributed renewable energy technologies are proven, sustainable, and inclusive solutions to Malawi's energy-access problem, powering economic growth and creating a wealth of new opportunities for education and enterprise. Other predominantly rural countries across the Global South should take note.

item.title: Why Is Everyone So Self-Righteous?
item.description: To evaluate an issue objectively, one must frame it “consequentially,” weighing various options and their likely real-world effects. But since this kind of analysis is difficult, it tends to be supplanted by a quasi-religious framing of issues in terms of inviolable sacred values.

item.title: Is Brazil’s Democracy Out of the Woods?
item.description: The conviction of former President Jair Bolsonaro for launching a coup will once again test the resilience of Brazilian democracy. Much will depend on whether Brazil's traditional conservatives continue to ally with the far right, as they did during Bolsonaro's presidency.

item.title: Seemingly Conscious AI Is Coming
item.description: Debates about whether AI truly can be conscious are a distraction. What matters in the near term is the perception that they are – and why the temptation to design AI systems that foster this perception must be resisted.

item.title: The US Will Rue Trump’s Trade War on India
item.description: The Indian economy will feel significant short-term pain from the steep tariffs imposed by US President Donald Trump. But India will adapt and emerge more resilient, while the US is jeopardizing its own long-term economic and geopolitical interests by alienating a rising trade partner and encouraging alternatives to the dollar.

item.title: Lower Interest Rates Are the Right Policy for the Wrong Reasons
item.description: There is strong evidence to support the case for interest-rate cuts in the United States, given the disproportionate impact of higher rates on the most vulnerable. Yet with Donald Trump loudly demanding that the US Federal Reserve lower borrowing costs, the situation has become more complicated than it needed to be.

item.title: Migration Is the Key to Global Prosperity
item.description: In many democracies nowadays, migration is discussed in visceral, emotional terms that bear little resemblance to reality. If that does not change, the future costs of mismanaging the issue will fall on everyone – not least the world's aging, fiscally strained democracies.

item.title: The False Promise of “AI for Social Good”
item.description: In peddling "AI for Social Good" initiatives, technology companies and philanthropies are suggesting that complex political, historical, and social issues can be reduced to technical problems. But given how today's AI systems work, there is no reason we should believe them – and much reason to be suspicious of their claims.

item.title: A New Multilateralism for the SDGs
item.description: The odds of reforming the multilateral system – which currently serves a few narrow interests – remain slim amid rising geopolitical tensions and growing populist sentiment in rich countries. To make progress on the Sustainable Development Goals, a more diverse group of actors must devise ways to circumvent systemic barriers.

item.title: Fulfilling the Promise of Private Development Finance
item.description: Private development finance was supposed to be a game-changer for sustainable development, but it has so far fallen short of expectations. But the recent proliferation of initiatives and alliances focused on de-risking such investments suggests that this might be about to change.

item.title: How Trade Fuels Illicit Financial Flows from Developing Countries
item.description: Trade has become a favored channel for those engaged in illicit or criminal activities because 80-85% of it is conducted via open-account trade, a bilateral transaction in which “goods are shipped and delivered before payment is due.” Addressing the issue won't be easy, but solutions exist.

item.title: South-South Is the Way to Global Financial Reform
item.description: Despite all the talk of reforming the global financial architecture to address development needs across the Global South, little progress will be made without a fundamental change in perspective. After all, the problem with the current system is that it disregards the conditions most developing countries face.

item.title: The Ocean Is the Next Geopolitical Battleground
item.description: The world’s maritime regions are hotter, more contested, and more fragile than ever before. As climate disruption collides with strategic competition, the ocean is re-emerging as a critical frontier in global geopolitics.
